metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: XML , XLink and XPointer
XLink is used to create hyperlinks in XML documents.
content.html: XLink is used to create hyperlinks in XML documents.

content.text: XLink Browser Support
There is no browser support for XLink in XML documents.
content.html: There is no browser support for XLink in XML documents.

content.text: However, all major browsers support XLinks in SVG .
content.html: However, all major browsers support XLinks in SVG.

content.text: XLink Syntax

In HTML, the <a> element defines a hyperlink. However, this is not how it works in XML. In XML documents, you can use whatever element names you want - therefore it is impossible for browsers to predict what link elements will be called in XML documents.
content.html: In HTML, the <a> element defines a hyperlink. However, this is not how it works in XML. In XML documents, you can use whatever element names you want - therefore it is impossible for browsers to predict what link elements will be called in XML documents.

content.text: Below is a simple example of how to use XLink to create links in an XML document:
content.html: Below is a simple example of how to use XLink to create links in an XML document:

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>


<homepages xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
 
<homepage xlink:type="simple"
xlink:href="https://www.w3schools.com">Visit W3Schools</homepage>
 
<homepage xlink:type="simple"
xlink:href="http://www.w3.org">Visit W3C</homepage>
</homepages>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<homepages xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
  <homepage xlink:type="simple" xlink:href="https://www.w3schools.com">Visit W3Schools</homepage>
  <homepage xlink:type="simple" xlink:href="http://www.w3.org">Visit W3C</homepage>
</homepages>

content.text: To get access to the XLink features we must declare the XLink namespace. The XLink namespace is: "http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink".
content.html: To get access to the XLink features we must declare the XLink namespace. The XLink namespace is: "http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink".

content.text: The xlink:type and the xlink:href attributes in the <homepage> elements come from the XLink namespace.
content.html: The xlink:type and the xlink:href attributes in the <homepage> elements come from the XLink namespace.

content.text: The xlink:type="simple" creates a simple "HTML-like" link (means "click here to go there").
content.html: The xlink:type="simple" creates a simple "HTML-like" link (means "click here to go there").

content.text: The xlink:href attribute specifies the URL to link to.
content.html: The xlink:href attribute specifies the URL to link to.

content.text: XLink Example
The following XML document contains XLink features:
content.html: The following XML document contains XLink features:

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>


<bookstore xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">


<book title="Harry Potter">


<description

xlink:type="simple"

xlink:href="/images/HPotter.gif"

xlink:show="new">


As his fifth year at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and


Wizardry approaches, 15-year-old Harry Potter is.......


</description>

</book>


<book title="XQuery Kick Start">


<description

xlink:type="simple"

xlink:href="/images/XQuery.gif"

xlink:show="new">


XQuery Kick Start delivers a concise introduction


to the XQuery standard.......


</description>

</book>


</bookstore>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<bookstore xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">

<book title="Harry Potter">
  <description
  xlink:type="simple"
  xlink:href="/images/HPotter.gif"
  xlink:show="new">
  As his fifth year at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and
  Wizardry approaches, 15-year-old Harry Potter is.......
  </description>
</book>

<book title="XQuery Kick Start">
  <description
  xlink:type="simple"
  xlink:href="/images/XQuery.gif"
  xlink:show="new">
  XQuery Kick Start delivers a concise introduction
  to the XQuery standard.......
  </description>
</book>

</bookstore>

content.text: Example explained:
content.html: Example explained:

content.text: XLink - Going Further
In the example above we have demonstrated simple XLinks. XLink is getting more interesting when accessing remote locations as resources, instead of standalone pages.
content.html: In the example above we have demonstrated simple XLinks. XLink is getting more interesting when accessing remote locations as resources, instead of standalone pages.

content.text: If we set the value of the xlink:show attribute to "embed", the linked resource should be processed inline within the page. When you consider that this could be another XML document you could, for example, build a hierarchy of XML documents.
content.html: If we set the value of the xlink:show attribute to "embed", the linked resource should be processed inline within the page. When you consider that this could be another XML document you could, for example, build a hierarchy of XML documents.

content.text: You can also specify WHEN the resource should appear, with the xlink:actuate attribute.
content.html: You can also specify WHEN the resource should appear, with the xlink:actuate attribute.

content.text: XLink Attribute Reference

content.code_html:
Attribute Value Description
xlink:actuate onLoad
onRequest
other
none		 Defines when the linked resource is read and shown:
  • onLoad - the resource should be loaded and shown when the document loads
  • onRequest - the resource is not read or shown before the link is clicked
xlink:href URL Specifies the URL to link to
xlink:show embed
new
replace
other
none		 Specifies where to open the link. Default is "replace"
xlink:type simple
extended
locator
arc
resource
title
none		 Specifies the type of link

content.text: XPointer
XPointer Browser Support
There is no browser support for XPointer. But XPointer is used in other XML languages.
content.html: There is no browser support for XPointer. But XPointer is used in other XML languages.

content.text: XPointer Example
In this example, we will use XPointer in conjunction with XLink to point to a specific part of another document.
content.html: In this example, we will use XPointer in conjunction with XLink to point to a specific part of another document.

content.text: We will start by looking at the target XML document (the document we are linking to):
content.html: We will start by looking at the target XML document (the document we are linking to):

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>


<dogbreeds>


<dog breed="Rottweiler" id="Rottweiler">


<picture url="https://dog.com/rottweiler.gif" />


<history>The Rottweiler's ancestors were probably Roman


drover dogs.....</history>


<temperament>Confident, bold, alert and imposing, the Rottweiler


is a popular choice for its ability to protect....</temperament>

</dog>


<dog breed="FCRetriever" id="FCRetriever">


<picture url="https://dog.com/fcretriever.gif" />


<history>One of the earliest uses of retrieving dogs was to


help fishermen retrieve fish from the water....</history>


<temperament>The flat-coated retriever is a sweet, exuberant,


lively dog that loves to play and retrieve....</temperament>

</dog>


</dogbreeds>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<dogbreeds>

<dog breed="Rottweiler" id="Rottweiler">
  <picture url="https://dog.com/rottweiler.gif" />
  <history>The Rottweiler's ancestors were probably Roman
  drover dogs.....</history>
  <temperament>Confident, bold, alert and imposing, the Rottweiler
  is a popular choice for its ability to protect....</temperament>
</dog>

<dog breed="FCRetriever" id="FCRetriever">
  <picture url="https://dog.com/fcretriever.gif" />
  <history>One of the earliest uses of retrieving dogs was to
  help fishermen retrieve fish from the water....</history>
  <temperament>The flat-coated retriever is a sweet, exuberant,
  lively dog that loves to play and retrieve....</temperament>
</dog>

</dogbreeds>

content.text: Note that the XML document above uses id attributes on each element!
content.html: Note that the XML document above uses id attributes on each element!

content.text: So, instead of linking to the entire document (as with XLink), XPointer allows you to link to specific parts of the document. To link to a specific part of a page, add a number sign (#) and an XPointer expression after the URL in the xlink:href attribute, like this: xlink:href="https://dog.com/dogbreeds.xml#xpointer(id('Rottweiler'))". The expression refers to the element in the target document, with the id value of "Rottweiler".
content.html: So, instead of linking to the entire document (as with XLink), XPointer allows you to link to specific parts of the document. To link to a specific part of a page, add a number sign (#) and an XPointer expression after the URL in the xlink:href attribute, like this: xlink:href="https://dog.com/dogbreeds.xml#xpointer(id('Rottweiler'))". The expression refers to the element in the target document, with the id value of "Rottweiler".

content.text: XPointer also allows a shorthand method for linking to an element with an id. You can use the value of the id directly, like this: xlink:href="https://dog.com/dogbreeds.xml#Rottweiler".
content.html: XPointer also allows a shorthand method for linking to an element with an id. You can use the value of the id directly, like this: xlink:href="https://dog.com/dogbreeds.xml#Rottweiler".

content.text: The following XML document contains links to more information of the dog breed for each of my dogs:
content.html: The following XML document contains links to more information of the dog breed for each of my dogs:

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>


<mydogs xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">


<mydog>


<description>


Anton is my favorite dog. He has won a lot of.....


</description>
 
<fact xlink:type="simple" xlink:href="https://dog.com/dogbreeds.xml#Rottweiler">
  Fact about Rottweiler 
  </fact>

</mydog>


<mydog>


<description>


Pluto is the sweetest dog on earth......


</description>


<fact xlink:type="simple" xlink:href="https://dog.com/dogbreeds.xml#FCRetriever">
  Fact about flat-coated Retriever 
  </fact>

</mydog>


</mydogs>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<mydogs xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">

<mydog>
  <description>
  Anton is my favorite dog. He has won a lot of.....
  </description>
  <fact xlink:type="simple" xlink:href="https://dog.com/dogbreeds.xml#Rottweiler">
  Fact about Rottweiler
  </fact>
</mydog>

<mydog>
  <description>
  Pluto is the sweetest dog on earth......
  </description>
  <fact xlink:type="simple" xlink:href="https://dog.com/dogbreeds.xml#FCRetriever">
  Fact about flat-coated Retriever
  </fact>
</mydog>

</mydogs>
